articles.editorNote:
When I read Brian's [Be Kind][bk] story, I immediately subscribed to his Monday Mailer newsletter. A while later I asked him if he'd be interested in writing something for Pony Foo, which he kindly agreed to. In this article, he writes about side projects. How to do **more** --- when you already do so much?

Enjoy!

[bk]: https://briangilham.com/blog/2016/10/10/be-kind

articles.summaryHtml: Earlier this year my team at Snyk added an interesting Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability to our database, in the popular marked package. The vulnerability is ‚Ä¶

articles.editorNote:
A while back I approached Guy from Snyk *-- a Node.js vulnerability detection and security firm --* and asked him to write about an interesting vulnerability his team identified and fixed. This blog post shows an example vulnerability and how easily things can go wrong *-- even when a package has been tested by several other users beforehand.*

Take it away, Guy!

articles.summaryHtml: Quite a few challenges have been found with using server-side sessions in modern-day applications. In this post, we‚Äôll identify those challenges and explain how JWT and sessions work in practice.
articles.title: JSON Web Tokens vs. Session Cookies: In Practice
articles.titleHtml: JSON Web Tokens vs. Session Cookies: In Practice
articles.editorNote:
There was a bit of controversy recently about the use cases where JWT really shines, and the ones where it doesn't do such a great job. Namely, are JSON web tokens good enough for sessions _-- or should we keep using cookies instead?_

[Prosper][author] from **Auth0** approached us about writing a guest post on Pony Foo, and he'll be addressing exactly those questions. üç™

[author]: /contributors/prosper-otemuyiwa "Check out Prosper's profile!"

articles.summaryHtml: A simple guide to getting up and running using Background Sync and Service Workers. Background Sync is a new web API that lets you defer actions until the user has stable connectivity. This makes it great for ensuring that whatever the user wants to send, is actually sent.
articles.title: ServiceWorker: A Basic Guide to BackgroundSync
articles.titleHtml: ServiceWorker: A Basic Guide to BackgroundSync
articles.editorNote:
*I'm super eager to share the first of many guest posts that will be featured on Pony Foo! üéâ*

When Dean came to me with the idea of writing an article on ServiceWorker, I was immediately thrilled with his proposal to write about BackgroundSync. I hadn't quite covered that area in previous [`serviceworker`][worker] articles, and he's put together a piece on what BackgroundSync is, how it works, and why it's useful.

[worker]: /articles/tagged/serviceworker "Articles on Pony Foo tagged 'serviceworker'"
